The Division of Health Professions offers career preparation in a variety of programs. Included is, the Associate Degree Nursing (RN) program, the Practical Nurse program, the Respiratory Care program, and the Medical Laboratory Technician program. All of the health profession programs have a strong science base and clinical component in addition to theory to prepare students for the registry or licensing examinations in their field.

body:
Welcome to English as a Second Language Program!

Our ESL Program offers credit-bearing courses for bilingual Spanish/English and non-native English speaking students. In other words, our students are admitted to RACC, eligible for financial aid, and work toward their college degree. ESL courses are also available to those who only seek to improve their English language proficiency.

Our student population, both U.S. resident and international, is diverse. Our students come from 17+ countries, including the United States of America, and speak 19 languages.

Our Mission

We nurture a culture of student success.

Our Goals

We are committed to:

  • helping students develop academic literacy, English proficiency, and study skills necessary for college and life success.
  • providing academic support throughout students’ careers at RACC.
  • inspiring students develop skills of effective team work in a multicultural setting.
  • enhancing respect to diversity at RACC.

Registration Process

To register for ESL courses, a student needs to apply for RACC, take a placement test, and submit FAFSA, an application for financial aid. Placement into ESL courses is based on scores on the reading and writing sections of placement test. After the placement test, a student should meet with an academic advisor or Dr. Elena Lawrick, ESL Program Coordinator, to register for appropriate ESL courses. Read about ESL courses here.

For more information about ESL courses, contact Dr. Elena Lawrick, ESL Program Coordinator at 610-372-4721 (ext. 5094). You can also keep up with the ESL Program on Facebook.

Looking forward to working with you,

Dr. Elena Lawrick
title: English as a Second Language Program

title: College Calendar

body:
Reading Area Community College (RACC) is an accredited, comprehensive, open-enrollment education institution that provides the following: Associate degree, Certificate and Diploma Programs; career-focused training; transitional coursework; skills training for business and industry; personal enrichment programs and public service activities. Sponsored by the Berks County Commissioners the College provides affordable access to meet identified community educational needs.

Students from every age, race, religion and many different countries throughout the world choose to study here. Those who are seeking degrees at the college are attracted to programs like nursing, respiratory care, criminal justice and business. Other people pursue individual courses to brush up on a skill or interest, or pursue certification in a variety of subjects. The Community Education/Workforce Development division offers programs like dental assisting, home health aide, veterinary assisting, ESL classes and GED preparation.

The College plays an important part in the business community as well. The new Schmidt Training and Technology Center provides training in senior leadership, manufacturing technology, information technology, workplace readiness and workplace literacy. RACC also partners with other community organizations to enhance the economic vitality of the city and county.

body:
Reading Area Community College encourages students to continue their academic pursuits outside of the classroom. Often the same written work you produce in your class can be used to present at conferences or even be published in our literary journal.

In addition to writing, there are numerous leadership opportunities on campus, including Student Government, a year-round Leadership Program and multiple student clubs with officer positions.

Have you always wanted to travel? A scholarship program through the business department and international travel through the Phi Theta Kappa honor society may help fulfill your dreams.

Finally, if you like to perform, there are multiple venues, highlighted by the annual RACC Idols competition each spring.

Writing and Research

Legacy – RACC's annual scholarly journal accepts submissions from students and invites students to join the editorial staff.

Front Street Journal – The College newspaper welcomes content from students and invites students to become staff writers and hold other editorial positions.

Ronald Borkert Award for Library Research – This campus competition is an opportunity for students to submit their traditional course research papers for the award. For more information, please contact Mary Ellen Heckman (mheckman@racc.edu).

The Beacon Conference – Students work with faculty mentors from their colleges to prepare and submit research papers that demonstrate outstanding scholarship and originality. Please contact Dr. Donna Singleton (dsingleton@racc.edu) for more information.

Higher Education Council of Berks County (HECBC) Undergraduate Research and Creativity Conference – This annual conference is open to students from each of the Berks County colleges and universities. Student presentations can be in the form of a paper presentation, poster, artwork, film or performance. Please contact RACC professor C.L. Costello (ccostello@racc.edu) for more information.

Reading Area Community College Colloquium – This annual showcase of student work represents each of the College's academic divisions. Please contact RACC professor C.L. Costello (ccostello@racc.edu) for more information.

Nota Bene – literary journal open to Phi Theta Kappa honor society members.

Leadership Opportunities

Phi Theta Kappa – RACC has a chapter of this international honor society for two-year schools.

Student Government Association – Open to all students at RACC who want to have their voice heard.

Student Professional Development & Leadership Program – A year-round program at RACC that provides students with educational opportunities to explore, identify, develop and enhance their leadership potential.

Foreign Study and Travel Opportunities

Danzer Foundation Scholarship – Each year a business student from RACC is invited to spend a semester studying in Reutlingen, Germany. Read about Maria Madera and Ryan Bertoldi who studied through this scholarship.

International Scholar Laureate Program – Phi Theta Kappa honor society students are offered foreign study opportunities. Read more about RACC students who have traveled on these trips.

Performance Opportunities

Norton Anthology Recitation Contest – College and high school students can submit their recitation of a famous work for this annual competition.

Bruce Stanley Memorial Poetry Series – RACC welcomes local poets to campus for this quarterly series that is open to everyone. Guests are invited to share their work during an open mic at the end of the event. For more information, please contact Sarah Hess (shess@racc.edu).

RACC Idols – A student talent competition held each winter with the winner and first runner-up advancing to Berks Got Talent. For more information, please contact Kim Uphold (kuphold@racc.edu).
title: Academic Enrichment

The Advising Center is your first stop for assistance with academic planning. The Advising Center has both faculty and staff advisors who are here to help you. Whether it is discussing different majors, selecting courses, or plans to transfer, the Advising Center staff can assist you.

Location: Berks Hall 209
Phone: 610-607-6245

Fall/Spring Walk-in Advising Hours

Additional times available by appointment

  • Monday:

  • 9:00 AM - 3:00 PM
  • 1:00 PM - 6:30 PM
  • 1:00 PM - 6:30 PM
  • 9:00 AM - 3:00 PM

Registration Dates

Registration for Fall classes is currently underway! View the registration dates & deadlines now.

Current Students

Students that are currently enrolled in courses with a declared academic program are assigned to a faculty academic advisor. You are strongly encouraged to meet with an advisor before registering for each semester, changing your current schedule (including dropping or withdrawing from classes), or changing your major. You can find your advisor, their office hours, and their contact information through WebAdvior

  1. Log in to WebAdvisor
  2. Select the Student option
  3. Select the Advisor's Office Hours option under the Academic Profile heading

Students may also visit the Advising Center in B209 for guidance and assistance.

New Students

We know that registering for college for the first time can be overwhelming, so we have designed a 1-step advising and registration process for new students. After you take your placement test and the tests are scored, you can meet with an advisor as a walk-in student during walk-in hours or you can schedule an appointment to finish the registration process.
title: Academic Advising

body:
The Human Resources Office is committed to providing service and assistance in a broad range of areas, including recruitment, benefits administration, compensation, and staff development and training. The Human Resources Office is committed to providing equal employment opportunities for all applicants to ensure that RACC’s staff reflects our commitment to quality education, to our diverse student body and to our surrounding community. As such the Faculty and Staff of Reading Area Community College are involved in a variety of instructional and non-instructional activities that contribute to the goals and objectives of a two-year public institution.

RACC offers competitive salaries and excellent fringe benefits, including health and dental insurance, retirement, paid leave time, holidays, life and long term disability insurance, educational assistance and a tuition waiver program.

The deadline date listed in the position advertisement is final. Application materials received after the deadline date shown on the position announcement will not be given consideration for the opening. RACC is an Affirmative Action/Equal Opportunity Employer

Human Resources Staff:

Christina Nelson, MBA, Human Resources Administrator
Katy Taveras, Human Resources Assistant
title: Human Resources

body:
Policy: It is the policy of Reading Area Community College to prohibit discrimination on the basis of race, color, sex, sexual orientation, religion, national or ethnic origin, age, disability, or status as a disabled or Vietnam Era veteran in regard to the administration of all campus programs, services and activities and the admission of students, employment actions, or other sponsored activities. Furthermore it is RACC's policy not to tolerate harassment of any type, including sexual harassment, of or by any employee, student, contractor, vendor, and/or visitor to Reading Area Community College.

In addition it is the policy of Reading Area Community College not to discriminate on the basis of sex in its educational programs and activities as required by Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972. Title IX provides that "No person in the United States shall, on the basis of sex, be excluded from participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any education program or activity receiving Federal financial assistance." Sex discrimination includes sexual harassment and sexual assault.

Affirmative Action inquiries should be directed to the Affirmative Action Officer, RACC, P.O. Box 1706, Reading, PA 19603 (610/372-4721). All colleges and universities, in compliance with the Pennsylvania College and University Security and Information Act of 1988 and the Student Right-to-Know and Campus Security Act, are required to provide information regarding safety and security procedures and statistics on campus. A copy of this report is available by contacting the Director of Safety and Security, Room 159, Berks Hall.
title: Affirmative Action And Nondiscrimination Policy

Reading Area Community College welcomes Diversity in terms of race, ethnicity, age, class, gender, ability, sexual orientation, and belief system among others.     Hopewell Furnace National Historical Site

    Address: #2 Mark Bird Lane
    Elverson, PA 19520

    Phone: (610)582-8773
    Library Contact: Frank Hebblewaite

    Library hours by appointment only
    Park Hours Sun - Sat 9:00 AM - 5:00 PM
    Admission: Adult (17 and up): $4.00
    Under 17: FREE

    URL: http://www.nps.gov/hofu

    Mr. Frank Hebblewaite at the Hopewell Furnace National Historic Site was very helpful with finding information pertaining to slavery and the underground railroad in Berks County. Hopewell offers a variety of resource information: computerized database, microfiche, and vertical file, containing documentation from genealogy to wills. He also has a great understanding of the Christiana Resistance, which can be found on page 52 of the hard copy of this directory.

    Hopewell also contains information about how Hopewell Furnace and Johanna Furnace, which is ten miles from Hopewell, shared slaves and work tactics involving slavery. An individual can also tour the Furnace and view the areas where the slaves worked and stayed while living on the site. Also, numerous sources of information can be found concerning Mark Bird, owner of Hopewell Furnace, the largest slave owner in Berks County during the slavery period. Overall, one will find useful information pertaining to slavery and the underground railroad in Berks County at Hopewell Furnace National Historic Site.

    Recommended books to view/purchase at Hopewell National Historic Site:
    "Underground Railroad"
    "Bond of Iron and Black Presence in Pennsylvania"

    Mr. Hebblewaite also recommends that those interested in visiting and learning about Hopewell Furnace, read "Hopewell Village, The Dynamics of a Nineteenth Century Iron-Making Community," by Joseph E. Walker.

    Daniel Boone Homestead

    Address: 400 Daniel Boone Road
    Birdsboro, PA 19508
    Phone: (610)582-4900
    Contact Person: Mr. Mike Emrich
    Park Hours: Tues - Sat 9:00 AM - 5:00 PM
    Sun 12:00 PM - 5:00 PM

    Age 6 - 12 $2.50
    Age 6 and under: FREE
    URL: http://www.berksweb.com/boone.html

    Mr. Mike Emrich of Daniel Boone Homestead is very helpful pertaining the the research of slavery in Berks County. Mike had copies of church records which states slave names and how they were accounted for in the town. He also has copies of wills which refer to the slave owners leaving property and other materials to their slaves. Mike also has reports from previous homestead workers who completed history research concerning slavery in Berks County. One can also take a tour of the homestead and view the historical places of Daniel Boone and experience the history of Berks County.

    Slavery in Pennsylvania Web Site

    Address: Harrisburg, PA

    Contact: Mr. George Nagle

    E-Mail: GNagle2919@aol.com

    URL: http://www.geocities.com/historian5

    Mr.Nagle, the web author of Slavery in Pennsylvania, is very helpful when it comes to the history of slavery and the underground railroad in Berks County. His website offers an individualized census taken in 1800. One can also find useful information concerning how slavery affected surrounding counties: Dauphin and Lancaster. Mr. Nagle also e-mailed me run-away slave ads from the Reading area dating back to 1758. He was very helpful when it came to e-mail, because he would always e-mail back within 24 hours. The website would be very useful to someone researching slavery and the Underground Railroad in Berks County and throughout Pennsylvania.

    Berks County Historical Society

    Address: 940 Centre Ave
    Reading, PA 19601

    Museum Hours
    Tues - Sat 9AM - 4PM
    Adults: $2.50
    Seniors: $2.00
    Age 5 - 12: $1.00

    Library Hours
    Tues - Sat 9AM - 4PM
    User Fee (non-members): $4.00/day
    Year Pass: $15.00

    URL: http://www.berksweb.com/histsoc/histsoc.html

    The Berks County Historical Society contains numerous amounts of information pertaining to Slavery and the Underground Railroad in Reading and Berks County, Pennsylvania. One will find newspaper articles, micro-films, mini-films, and documentation pertaining to slavery trials and slave censuses. A researcher can find additional information in past resident scrapbooks and past church and township records. The Historical Society also carries a set of books titled "The Historical Review of Berks County," which one will find useful in finding information on Underground Railroad sites and local slave owners. Also, the staff at the Berks County Historical Society is very helpful and attentive to ones needs. A researcher can also use the computers in the library to research information within the Historical Society and on the internet.

    Email: jlawlor@racc.edu or jmlawlor@comcast.net

    Scope of Term Project

    At the beginning of the Spring 2000 term at Reading Area Community College, I undertook a History Term Project to complete in History of the United States I. I have always been interested in slavery and the underground railroad in Berks County after learning that slavery did occur in this part of the country. I have also learned that Reading and Berks County was on the route of the runaway slaves escaping to Canada and nearby communities. During a meeting my instructor, John Lawlor, we designed a project that would benefit the Underground Railroad Project, which is a study of Underground Railroad Sites throughout Berks County, Pennsylvania and Montgomery County in Maryland.

The Foundation for Reading Area Community College was created to raise, invest and manage private funds for the benefit of the College. The Foundation supports RACC's mission to build communities of learning to encourage educational growth by providing scholarship funding for all students with demonstrated financial need and for emerging initiatives that serve to further enhance the College's programs and facilities.

The Foundation for RACC is a nonprofit organization under section 501 (c) (3) of the Internal Revenue Code. The official registration and financial information of the Foundation for Reading Area Community College may be obtained from the Pennsylvania Department of State by calling toll free, within Pennsylvania, 1-800-732-0999. Registration does not imply endorsement.

28th Annual Golf Tournament

Brochure and Registration Information - PDF 127 KB

We're excited to announce a new way that you can help support the Foundation for RACC.

Foundation For Reading Area Community College

AmazonSmile is a simple and automatic way for you to support your favorite charitable organization every time you shop on Amazon.com, at no cost to you. When you shop at smile.amazon.com, you'll find the exact same Amazon.com selections, with the added bonus that the AmazonSmile Foundation will donate 0.5% of the purchase price from your eligible AmazonSmile purchases to your favorite charitable organization, which now includes the Foundation for RACC.

Please consider the Foundation when you make your Amazon.com purchases and together, we can support our students and to provide them with the knowledge and skills they need to be successful.

For more information, contact foundation@racc.edu or 610-607-6239.

body:
Can your résumé pass the 30 second scan?

  • Keep it short and simple (KISS)
  • Do not write in paragraphs or sentences
  • Use simple language
  • Stress achievements
  • Don't mention salary
  • Don't exaggerate
  • Use a one-inch margin on all four sides
  • Choose an easy-to-read font
  • Use bold caps for headings
  • Proofread for spelling and grammar
  • Make quality copies
  • Use one page
  • Use action verb phrases
  • Be specific; give examples
  • Be positive
  • Don't list references
  • Use standard 8.5 by 11" paper
  • Double space between sections
  • Use bullets for emphasis
  • Show your résumé to a professional
  • Format résumé correctly so it can be sent as an attachment
title: Résumé Tips

body:
A Sample Cover Letter for an Internship

1010 Anywhere Lane
Reading, PA 19603

March 15, 2008

Ms. Amanda Paulson
Universal Orlando
1000 Universal Studios Plaza
Orlando, Florida 32819-7610

Dear Ms. Paulson,

My unique mix of previous work experience and my status as a Reading Area Community College student studying marketing, make me an ideal candidate for a summer internship with Universal Orlando.

My experience in sales and customer relationship management, combined with my courses in marketing, has convinced me that hospitality marketing is a career option I would like to explore.

More importantly, an internship with Universal Orlando would be mutually beneficial. Your company has an excellent reputation for customer satisfaction, and I know that the combination of my experience, education, and motivation to excel will make me an asset to your marketing department.

I am sure that it would be worthwhile for us to meet. I will contact you within a week to arrange a meeting. Should you have any questions before that time, you may reach me via phone (386-555-2922) or via email (cappleton@racc.edu).

Thank you for your time and consideration.


Sincerely,


Christina Appleton

A Sample Cover Letter for a New College Graduate

45 Lincoln Lane
Reading, PA 19601

June 10, 2009

Mr. Archie Weatherby
California Investments, Inc.
25 Sacramento Street
San Francisco, CA 94102

Dear Mr. Weatherby,

My outgoing personality, my sales experience, and my recently completed education make me a strong candidate for a position as an insurance broker for California Investments, Inc.

I recently graduated from Reading Area Community College with a degree in business, where I was president of the Student Government Association and a Raven Ambassador.

Although a recent graduate, I am not a typical new graduate. I attended school in Michigan, Arizona, and Oregon. And I've put myself through these schools by working such jobs as radio advertising sales, newspaper subscription sales, and bartending, all of which enhanced my formal education.

I have the maturity, skills, and abilities to embark on a career in insurance brokering, and I'd like to do this in California, my home state.

I will be in California at the end of this month, and I'd like very much to talk with you concerning a position at California Investments. I will follow up this letter with a phone call to see if I can arrange a time to meet with you.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,


John Oakley
title: Sample Cover Letters

body:
Choosing Three Great References

Suggestions include the following:

Department heads, directors, deans, instructors, counselors
Present employers (Be careful unless your employer knows that you wish to leave).
Past employers, supervisors, and managers.

Alternative References

You might include one from the following:

Colleagues in prior or present jobs (be careful).
Subordinates (be careful).
Suppliers and clients
Volunteer committee chairpersons

Reference Information

It is best to add the following to each of your referenced names:

Name
Title
Company
Address
Phone - Ask your reference if he/she prefers listing of work or home phone number.
E-mail and/or fax numbers if reference agrees

AHEDD

1150 Berkshire Blvd.
Wyomissing PA 19610
Phone: (610)375-7692
e-mail: AHEDD@paonline.com (Administrative Office)
Hours: 8:30 am - 4:30 pm Monday - Friday

Agency Information- AHEDD is a private, non-profit agency that was founded in 1977 to provide employment and training services to persons with disabilities. Around 1991, AHEDD expanded and began providing similar services to those receiving welfare. AHEDD currently employs 55 people and provides employment and training services in at least 14 Pennsylvania Counties and three Dover Counties. The offices serving these counties are located in the following areas: Philadelphia, Bucks County, Harrisburg, Lebanon, York, Reading, Lancaster, Pittsburgh, and Dover, DE.

Programs- AHEDD officers a variety of individualized and group services to individuals with disabilities and people receiving welfare. All those seeking employment can receive assistance with: resume preparation; appropriate completion of job applications; job interviews; job search; training assistance at the job site; counseling for job related concerns; transportation training; and follow up services to ensure that the individual is satisfied with their job and meeting the expectations of the employer.

Eligibility Criteria- The basic criteria for individuals referred to AHEDD are; they must have a documented disability that limits their ability to secure and maintain employment and be willing to seek employment.
In addition to AHEDD's criteria, certain funding source may impose additional requirements for eligibility. Requirements can vary between funding sources; therefore, individuals interested in services should call AHEDD for more information. AHEDD's welfare programs require that the individual be determined eligible and be referred by his/her local County Assistance Office.

Accessibility- AHEDD's offices are accessible and barrier free. As for the accessibility of services, AHEDD ensures that all services are accessible to individuals with disabilities as required under the ADA and Rehabilitation Act.

Languages Spoken- Interpreters are provided by AHEDD where appropriate to overcome any language barriers.

Agency Information- ADAPPT HOUSE is a residential facility contracted to the PA Department of Corrections for the benefit of pre-release and parole community corrections candidates to provide both chemical dependency treatment and group home services. The chemical dependency program involves both group and individual therapy that is reality based, concentrating on preparing each client to cope drug and alcohol free upon reentry to independent living. Group Home residency is designed to assist clients in acquiring basic living skills to cope in our ever-changing society.

Programs- Intensive Drug and Alcohol Program - up to 45 days, Dual Diagnosis, Therapeutic Work Cadre, ADAPPT - YouthBuild Program, Job Placement Program, ADAPPT Urinalysis Program, Group Residence Program

Eligibility Criteria- Admission to ADAPPT HOUSE is open to both men and women who have a history of chemical dependency and are pre-release candidates or parolees of the PA Department of Corrections. Each person is evaluated on a case by case acceptance basis.

Accessibility- N/A

Languages Spoken- English and Spanish.

body:
SUPPORT GROUP INFORMATION

Panic Disorder: Nearly two percent of Americans will experience panic disorder during their lives. Panic attacks appear suddenly without any apparent cause. This may include chest pains, a racing or pounding heartbeat, dizziness, nausea, difficulty breathing, a sense of terror, and a fear of dying or losing control.
title: SUPPORT GROUP INFORMATION

body:
Autism/Asperger's Family Alliance

First Monday of each month  (except July)
12noon-1pm & 5:30-6:30pm

Call: Janice Fetrow-Stewart LSW, ACSW
610-775-2836 for details & directions
limited group seating

Location: Wyomissing, PA

Agency Information:

DO YOU HAVE A CHILD WITH AUTISM OR ASPERGER’S?
The AUTISM/ASPERGER’S FAMILY ALLIANCE Program
Is Designed For You!
 
Healthy Parenting Training/Support-Groups
  • Parenting can be overwhelming and isolating, especially if you are dealing with children with special needs.
  • Be supported in finding your own strengths as a parent.
  • Discover the resources and skills to rebuild positive family relationships.

Children Socialization-Groups

  • Children will be supported through communication/socialization technique, games and creative arts.

Individual Counseling

  • Individual counseling will be provided by a Licensed Social Worker (LSW) & Associates.

Individual Deep Relaxation & Energy Healing

  • This proven form of energy work offers a deep sense of peacefulness through intention based talk therapy and positive energy healing technique while the individual rests comfortably during the session. Provided by a LSW/Certified Energy Healer.
title: Autism/Asperger's Family Alliance

    The Underground Railroad Project

    Student Activities:

    Step one: Visit the tool kit page at Montgomery College

    Ideas about activities for student involvement:

    • Consider reseach in any of a number of topics
    • Compile bibliographies of national, state, and local resources
    • Perform general research on the topics of slavery and resistance
    • Analyze escape routes through the local area
    • Identify and research stations in the local area
    • Research local court records and newspapers for cases relating to fugitive slaves.
    • Research local resistance to slavery
    • Photograph sites and digitize documents
    • Participate in activites of local historical organizations
    • Participate in web site design and development
    • Collaborate with faculty and students at partner institution.

    Underground Railroad Project Home Page
    RACC's Home Page

    Last updated 02/03/2000

    Central Pennsylvania African American Museum

    Bethel AME Church
    Address: 119 N. 10th Street
    Reading, PA 19601
    Phone: (610)371-8713
    Contact: Mr. Frank Gilyard
    URL: http://www.cr.nps.gov/nr/travel/underground/pa3.htm
    Misc. Info: Guided tour of museum and a view of the PIT (where the runaway slaves hid).
    Hours: Saturdays 1:00 - 4:00 PM other days by appointment
    Admission: $3.00
    12 or younger: $1.50
    Seniors: $2.00

    Mr. Frank Gilyard at the CPAAM is very knowledgeable in the historical preservation of African Americans, slavery, and the underground railroad in Berks County. Being on the tour of the museum and the sight of the pit, one can experience a connection to the time of slavery. The museum contains documentation to the first black people in Berks County. The CPAAM can also connect an individual to other locations throughout the county that served as stations for the underground railroad. Mr. Gilyard tells of stories of how slavery and segregation still has an effect on present day life, all connecting to the start of slavery. Mr. Gilyard is a very interesting person to listen to especially concerning the history of Berks County and how the Bethel AME Church was the first African American church in Berks County.

    Slavery in Berks County

    "We know from the Federal Census reports and from some faded yellow bills of sale, still preserved in our Court House, that there were slaves, mostly house servants, in Berks and in the county seat of Reading up to 1820" (Shenton & Weber 18). Thomas Penn, one of the founders of the city of Reading, owned a well-known slave by the name of Virgil Warder (Johnson 159). Another recognized slave, Dinah Clark, "engaged in almost every class of work generally done by strong men. She was born a slave on a farm in Bern township. When a small girl she was sold for $100 and received her freedom at the age of 21. After that she made her home in Reading" (Underground).

    According to Berks County's Record of Slaves, 138 slaves were registered by 46 different slaveholders between June 9, 1780, and September 13, 1825. Out of these, 119 were recorded before November 1, 1780 and 19 were recorded as having been born after that date. The first two entries were both female slaves owned by two members of the Berks County Bar Association. "The first  Phyllis, 24 years of age, was the property of James Biddle, Esq., the first member of the Berks County Bar and later the first President Judge of the Court of Common Pleas of Philadelphia. The second  Elizabeth, 22 years of age, a slave belonging to Collinson Read, Esq., another member of the Bar and the son of James Read, our first Prothonotary" (Schaeffer 5).

    According to Schaeffer, the largest slaveholders in Berks County in 1780 were:

    Mark Bird, of Birdsboro, with 18 slaves; John Lesher, of Oley Forge at what is now Spangsville, Oley Township, with 15; John Patton, who married the widow of William Bird, the father of Mark, and carried on the Berkshire Furnace in Lower Heidelberg (now South Heidelberg) Township, 14 slaves; George Ege, of Charming Forge, Marion Township, 10 slaves; Christian Lower, of Tulpehocken Township, 8 slaves; and Samuel Mifflin, merchant, of Reading, 5 slaves (5).

    All of these slave owners were iron-masters with the exception of Mifflin who was a businessman.

    Hopewell Furnace, owned by Mark Bird, the largest slave owner in Berks County, used African American workers. Bird's "slaves were put to work at his forges in Birdsboro, and are said to have dug Hopewell's original headrace, which powered a water wheel that, in turn, provided air to fire the furnace there" (Davis 5). "No positive proof was found that slaves were used at Hopewell, but the records were clear that Mark Bird possessed slaves during the time he was the owner of the Furnace" (Walker 305).

    "On the other hand there were circumstances which indicate that Negroes from the South worked here. Most of the 107 names collected from the Hopewell books appeared very briefly, often only one entry, to suggest the possibility of persons passing through" (Walker 307). For example, "'Black Frank' worked for 15 days in the autumn of 1802 and was not heard from again. 'Black Dine' came on June 22,1803, and on July 14 'went away' after collecting her wages. 'Black Luce' served as a maid for 10 weeks" (Walker 310). One could only speculate why these workers were transient.

    According to Walker, "Israel Acrelius observed many Negro slaves working at the Pennsylvania furnaces during his travels in the 1750's. He thought they were better treated here than anywhere else in America" (305). It is not surprising that iron masters in Berks County had more male slaves than female slaves. There was one exception. John Lesher's group was composed of 3 men, 3 women, 5 boys, and 4 girls (Schaeffer 5). Since males were more valuable to iron masters, one might question Lesher's rationale.

    As to whether slaves in Berks County took on the surnames of their masters, authorities seem to agree that this did not happen in the North to the extent it did in the South. "There were no known Blacks in Berks County with name Potts, Bird, Ege, Old, Lesher, Rutter, etc. There was, however, one indentured mulatto owned by George Ege whose name was George Greenfield. The indenture revealed that this mulatto at the age of six was owned by one James Greenfield; hence it is quite unlikely that the identical surname of the two is a coincidence"(Johnson 161).

    Sometimes a slave's name might be an indicator of his heritage. For example, Ebo was a slave who was listed in the personal inventory and appraisements of William Bird of Robeson Township. "The Ibos are a tribe in West Africa located in what is now the southern part of the Federation of Nigeria. They are a highly intelligent people trained by the British in the ways of business. Names such as Ebo, therefore, give one a clue as to the tribal origins of certain Blacks in this country" (Johnson 161).

    Sometimes a name reflected the slave's relationship with his master. For instance, "Joseph E. Walker refers to a runaway slave belonging to Mark Bird by the name of Cuff Dix and maintains that the name 'Cuff' was used for slaves who were troublemakers. This probably explains the origin of its colloquial usage among elderly blacks while chaffing each other" (Johnson 161).

    Unfortunately, some slaves in Berks County were mistreated by their masters. "A tourist in Berks County in 1928 describes a 'slave pen' seen in the cellar of a Berks County farms.The 'slave pen' was 9'X10' in size and was constructed with 2" X 2" bars spaced about five inches apart. The practice of having slave pens was very common as they were seen on other nearby farms"(Johnson 187).

    Many slaves attempted to escape their masters despite the consequences. Edward R. Turner, a leading authority on slavery in Pennsylvania, states that "runaways were frequently caught by the local authorities, who put them in jail, advertised for the masters to come and get them, and kept them until the masters came, or if they did not come, perhaps set them free"(Johnson 185).

    Sometimes runaway slaves were worth a lot of money to their owners. "Ten dollars was an appreciable amount of money in 1800. It paid a month's wages for a team driver; two days of a congressman's salary; bought ten subscriptions to The Weekly Advertiser, or bought three books" (Johnson 188). Even Mark Bird advertised for runaway slaves. "Cuff Dix, a skilled hammerman, escaped in 1774 and again in 1775; in the latter year he was apprehended in Delaware but disappeared from the New Castle jail before he could be returned to Bird"(Walker 305).

    Both anonymous and signed ads were placed in local newspapers for the hire and sale of blacks. "While most of the ads appearing in the Reading papers were, to be sure, anonymous, there were ads for both hire and sale of Blacks signed by one William Bell.It is quite possible that some of the unsigned ads also belonged to Bell"(Johnson 186). "There is strong evidence indicating that William Bell was, indeed, a slave broker. Deed books in the county courthouse further show that he owned property throughout the county, some of it in areas where there were iron furnaces with Black people in the close proximity"(Johnson186). "The Reading Zeitung of Dec. 29, 1800 contains the advertisement of William Bell, who offers a 'stray Negro Wench' for sale. 'She has had small pox and is industrious.' In the same newspaper on the same date Fred K. Bechtel offers at public sale 'a Negro man about 26 years old, strong and hardy'" (Underground)

    Sometimes ads appeared that would offer a slave's time such as the one in The Weekly Advertiser for January 28, 1804: "TO BE SOLD THE TIME OF A NEGRO MAN, who has to serve two years and eleven Months-he understands Farming and driving a Wagon-he is honest"(Johnson 185). Another ad had a very unusual twist. It read "TO BE SOLD THE TIME OF A YOUNG AND HEALTHY NEGRO WENCH.The Owner will not dispose of her to any person living in or around the borough of Reading" (Johnson 185). One could only imagine what be the motivating factor behind running such an ad.

    Two cartoons were discovered with an anti-slavery theme. One was taken from Readinger Adler Magazine of 1819. "It affords an interesting side-light on the abolition sentiment in our country four decades before the Civil War, which ended with the suppression of slavery (Shenton & Weber 18). The second, "also dealing with local slavery, is a relic of the bitter gubernatorial campaign of 1820 in Pennsylvania, when our own Joseph Hiester was opposing William Findlay. This cartoon shows Hiester savagely wielding the lash over cringing negroes" (Shenton & Weber 18). It is evident that the same political smear campaigns that occur today existed even back then.

    The local newspaper also relayed stories of various murders and insurrections that occurred throughout the country. "One killing that occurred in a neighboring county was reported in The Weekly Advertiser. 'We hear, a Negro man, named Butler, was taken up in Northampton County-for killing his Master and Mistress-and passed thro' this place for Lancaster'"(Johnson 188).

    No case ever stirred up such anxiety as the arrest of a fugitive slave. This was very unusual in that ninety percent of the courtroom audience consisted of black men and women. Cooley, a slave owner from Maryland, swore out a warrant for the arrest of "James Turner, commonly called Jim, a colored man, who had escaped from the 'labor and service' of Cooley." The judge (without the assistance of a jury) listened to the evidence and ruled in Turner's favor (Fryer).

    William Still, author of the book Underground Railroad, had ties to Berks County. According to Frank Gilyard, President of the Central Pennsylvania African American Museum (CPAAM), "Still's brother, Edgar, was a runaway slave who came to Berks County. Edgar was the founder of the colored Elks on Walnut Street in Reading. He is still recognized the first Sunday in May. He had a daughter who graduated from Albright College but was not able to gain employment in this area."

    The wooded area of southeastern Pennsylvania was the perfect sanctuary for slaves escaping from the South. In addition, many individuals risked helping these refugees. "George Washington wrote to a friend on November 20, 1786, that it was almost impossible to recover a negro who made his way to this area because there were so many people who would 'facilitate the escape'" (Walker 306-307). This underground network of individuals would be part of the "Underground Railroad and the 'train' would occasionally be nicknamed the 'Gospel Train'"(Dobard 62). "It is the story of a people's struggle for freedom echoed in the words of Harriet Tubman and Frederick Douglas declaring their intentions to 'live free or die'" (Dobard 66).

    Berks County was part of the Underground Railroad. Many of Hopewell and Joanna Furnace's African-American workers lived in the nearby forest called Six Penny Creek. "From 1835 on, this area became known as a safe haven for runaway slaves . The fugitives traveled across the Hopewell hills to the home of Quakers Elizabeth Scarlett and her son, Joseph (owners of Scarlett's Mills)" (Davis 5). "The forested hills and the remote huts of the colliers and wood cutters made ideal hiding places until the search ended and it was safe to move on north. While they were hiding, the Negroes could earn their food and some money" (Walker 307).

    Churches also played a major role in abolition movement. "These included the Quakers, members of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, the Methodist Church, the Presbyterian Church, the Baptist Church, and the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church" (Dobard 63). "Learning the language and the rituals of Christianity allowed the slaves to gather together and sing and speak with words that held one meaning for the masters, another for the slaves. Many hymns and spirituals were interpreted by the slaves and contained hidden meanings"(Dobard 60). In order to prevent this, "Laws were passed to curtail such communication, including . drumming, since it was feared to be a means of secret communication brought over from Africa" (Dobard 64-65). After the "talking drum" was banned, slaves used songs to transmit their messages (Gilyard). "A great deal of Christian symbols and songs about the Underground Railroad was conveyed through encoded songs and became the rallying cry for many a slave in need of persevering grace and in search of the 'promised land'"(Dobard 60).

    Quilts were also used to relay messages. Recently, a secret code designed by slaves was revealed. The Quilt Code "confirms the use of quilts as visual maps to freedom" (Dobard 67). For example, the Monkey Wrench pattern told the slaves to get the gather all necessary tools. The Wagon Wheel pattern "signaled the slaves to pack all the things that would go in a wagon or that would be used in transit." The Tumbling Boxes pattern indicated that it was time to escape. "The code had dual meaning: first to signal slaves to prepare to escape and second to give clues and indicate directions on the journey" (Dobard 70).

    Mt. Frisby A.M.E. Church, located in Birdsboro, was a place where "runaways could rest and re-group before continuing the trip to more northern regions" (Davis 5). "This church has the largest slave cemetery in Pennsylvania that is currently being maintained by the Cole family" (Gilyard).

    Another church that was active in the Underground Railroad was the Bethel AME Church located in Reading. "Built in 1837, Bethel is the only AME church in Berks County that was constructed through the private resources of its congregation, many of whom were employed in Reading's iron industry" (NPS). It was here that an underground hideaway called 'The Pit' was used to 'hide as many as twenty slaves' (Gilyard). "Jacob Ross, one of the founding members of the church, was himself a runaway slave from Virginia who had found support in the local black community and decided to settle in Reading" (NPS).

    Recently, Jason P. Shellenhamer, a senior anthropology student at Franklin and Marshall College, made an interesting discovery, on a property off route 61, in Ontelaunee Township. He uncovered evidence of a tunnel system that was "likely part of the Underground Railroad.The tunnel starts at the barn, which would have been a strategic location for slaves who traveled along rivers and creeks en route to Canada" (Henshaw 1). The original builder, Thomas Parvin, was a Quaker who "signed a statement for the abolition of slavery.according to a genealogical report" (Henshaw 1).

    Since the newspaper article was written on October 11, 2000, additional evidence has been unearthed. "Blue beads and three collars have been found. Blue beads were a 'sign' that slaves left behind to show they were there" (Gilyard).

    Unfortunately, this scenario has a disheartening twist. A lawsuit is pending which may prevent the preservation of this historical marker. It is unfortunate that a road that would destroy a piece of history may take precedence over this matter.

    It is no wonder that slaves found salvation in Berks County. Many individuals were committed to their cause. Although there were those who opposed the abolition of slavery, many more detested the idea of owning another individual. They found it appalling that a person could be the personal "property" of another. Slavery is part of our history that must not be ignored.



    Robin Wagar
    28 November 2000

    The Underground Railroad Project

    Goals:

    • Encourage scholarly student research into the existance and nature of the underground railroad nationally and within the localities served by the project partners.
    • develop and support a common historical resource relating to the underground railroad
    • foster intercollegial collaboration in the development of  a central web site and related web sites at partner institutions.
    "This site is a collaborative effort seeking to trace the path taken in the quest for freedom. It involves the efforts of both students and faculty members at Montgomery College in Maryland and Reading Area Community College in Pennsylvania to explore local and regional history dealing with the achievement of freedom. It adopts both a topical and a chronological approach. It is a work in progress and is open to contributions from others. If you or your students think they might contribute to the work, please contact the Web Master." -- Professor Duane Ellison, Montgomery College, Maryland.

The scholarships listed here are administered through the Foundation for RACC. They are either funded by the Foundation or an outside company who is working with the College to identify qualified candidates.

All Foundation for Reading Area Community College Scholarships are awarded according to financial aid and donor criteria. Foundation Scholarships are credited to the students’ financial aid account and are disbursed according to financial aid time lines and policies. Non-need based scholarships are awarded through the Foundation by faculty/staff recommendations. However, most Foundation Scholarships are need-based. When applying for a scholarship, students should check the eligibility criteria listed on the application to make sure they qualify. For a complete listing of RACC Scholarships and criteria, contact the Foundation for Reading Area Community College. Award amounts are determined on an annual basis by donor contributions, the Foundation Board of Directors and the financial need of the student.

Students with financial need for tuition, fees or books should fill out the “Foundation for Reading Area Community College Scholarship Application” listed below. After submitting this application, you will be matched with the Foundation Scholarship which best fits your characteristics for scholarship consideration. When there is more than one eligible applicant for the same scholarship, students with the highest academic performance, most financial need and those enrolled for the most number of credits are considered first. A current Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is required for all Foundation Scholarships. Scholarships are awarded annually; eligibility is determined on an annual basis.

    Bridges at Penn Street Over the Schuylkill River

    Penn Street Covered Bridges Images digitized at the Pennsylvania State Archives
    View 1   
    View 2    
    View 3

      Click on image to enlarge
    Note: Reading, PA is in the background

     

    Iron Bridge from upstream - East side of the river.
    Photograph of photograph at the Historical Society of Berks County
    Click on image of larger view - View 4

    Concrete from downstream--East side of the river.
    Taken from the window of the Yocum Library at Reading Area Community College
    Click on the above photograph to enlarge View 5

    Doing things... The artwork shown below was painted in 1862
    These are scenes from an artwork entitled View of Schuylkill Canal 1862 Northward from Penn Street Bridge by J. Heyl Raser.
    Original on display at the Historical Society of Berks County.
    Note:  these images were taken without flash and then photoenhanced.

    Questions:

    • Why was the first Penn Street bridge (1815) covered?
    • The bridge keeper was an important job.  Why?
    • What do you think?  Did the bridge keeper remove snow from the bridge during the winter?
    • Some of the images show the canal.  Which ones?
    • Why the switch from a wooden bridge to an iron one?
    • The photograph of the concrete bridge is from a window in the Yocum Library that is just south of Penn Street on the east side of the river.  What was this property used for in 1737?
    • What do you suppose the person in the painting might be thinking about?
    • What was the major event happening nationally at the time?
    • What are some of the items you can identify in the artwork?
    • What direction are you facing as you view the artwork?
    • Using your hand drawn map, see if you can identify the camera location used for each of the bridge photographs, views 1 through 5  Label them as v1, v2, v3, v4 and v5

My free advice to students:

The PHD Principle: Perseverance, Hard Work, and Determination

As an instructor and advisor, many students often ask me how to be successful academically. And I share with them one thing: The PHD Principle: Perseverance, Hard Work and Determination.

Perseverance is defined as steady persistence in adhering to a course of action, a belief, or a purpose; steadfastness; or what one may call "stick-to-it-ness". Be committed to your commitments. Remember the story of the tortoise and the hare: The race is not always won by the fastest but the one that can endure the longest.

Hard Work. We have all heard that anything worth having is worth working for. You must be willing to invest in your academic success by putting the necessary time and energy into your classes. Studies show that students must study one hour for every credit hour registered.

Lastly, Determination is defined as firmness of purpose; resolve. Turn your dream in to reality by being serious in your efforts and finishing the drill.

When the PHD principle–Perseverance, Hard Work, and Determination–is employed, academic success is sure to follow.

5 Tips for Academic Success

  1. Make a to-do list every day.
    Put things that are most important at the top of the list and do them first. And don't forget to reward yourself for your accomplishments.
  2. Make sure the faculty knows you.
    Sit in the front of the classroom. Participate in class discussions. Consult with your teachers during office hours.
  3. Review your notes every day.
    Reviewing helps you reinforce what you have learned, so you need less time to study before a test. You'll also be ready if you get called on in class or have to take a pop quiz.
  4. Establish a regular study routine, and study during daylight hours.
    Find a place that is comfortable–but not too comfortable–and always do your studying there, preferably during the same hours each day. Also, keep in mind that you're about 1.5 times more productive during daylight hours than when the sun is down.
  5. Keep your eyes on the prize.
    Clarify your goals. Know why you are in college in the first place. Visualize your success on daily basis.

Breaking Health News

Ansumana 2014 Lancet - Ebola in Sierra Leone - A Call to Action - PDF 119 KB

Frequently asked questions on Ebola virus disease (EVD)

1. What is Ebola virus disease?
Ebola virus disease (formerly known as Ebola haemorrhagic fever) is a severe, often fatal illness, with a death rate of up to 90%. The illness affects humans and nonhuman primates (monkeys, gorillas, and chimpanzees).
Ebola first appeared in 1976 in two simultaneous outbreaks, one in a village near the Ebola River in the Democratic Republic of Congo, and the other in a remote area of Sudan.
The origin of the virus is unknown but fruit bats (Pteropodidae) are considered the likely host of the Ebola virus, based on available evidence.

2. How do people become infected with the virus?
In the current outbreak in West Africa, the majority of cases in humans have occurred as a result of human-to-human transmission.
Infection occurs from direct contact through broken skin or mucous membranes with the blood, or other bodily fluids or secretions (stool, urine, saliva, semen) of infected people. Infection can also occur if broken skin or mucous membranes of a healthy person come into contact with environments that have become contaminated with an Ebola patient's infectious fluids such as soiled clothing, bed linen, or used needles.
More than 100 health-care workers have been exposed to the virus while caring for Ebola patients. This happens because they may not have been wearing personal protection equipment or were not properly applying infection prevention and control measures when caring for the patients. Health-care providers at all levels of the health system – hospitals, clinics, and health posts – should be briefed on the nature of the disease and how it is transmitted, and strictly follow recommended infection control precautions.
WHO does not advise families or communities to care for individuals who may present with symptoms of Ebola virus disease in their homes. Rather, seek treatment in a hospital or treatment centre staffed by doctors and nurses qualified and equipped to treat Ebola virus victims. If you do choose to care for your loved one at home, WHO strongly advises you to notify your local public health authority and receive appropriate training, equipment (gloves and personal protective equipment [PPE]) for treatment, instructions on proper removal and disposal of PPE, and information on how to prevent further infection and transmission of the disease to yourself, other family members, or the community.
Additional transmission has occurred in communities during funerals and burial rituals. Burial ceremonies in which mourners have direct contact with the body of the deceased person have played a role in the transmission of Ebola. Persons who have died of Ebola must be handled using strong protective clothing and gloves and must be buried immediately. WHO advises that the deceased be handled and buried by trained case management professionals, who are equipped to properly bury the dead.
People are infectious as long as their blood and secretions contain the virus. For this reason, infected patients receive close monitoring from medical professionals and receive laboratory tests to ensure the virus is no longer circulating in their systems before they return home. When the medical professionals determine it is okay for the patient to return home, they are no longer infectious and cannot infect anyone else in their communities. Men who have recovered from the illness can still spread the virus to their partner through their semen for up to 7 weeks after recovery. For this reason, it is important for men to avoid sexual intercourse for at least 7 weeks after recovery or to wear condoms if having sexual intercourse during 7 weeks after recovery.
Generally, a person must come into contact with an animal that has Ebola and it can then spread within the community from human to human.

3. Who is most at risk?
During an outbreak, those at higher risk of infection are:

  • health workers;
  • family members or others in close contact with infected people;
  • mourners who have direct contact with the bodies of the deceased as part of burial ceremonies.

More research is needed to understand if some groups, such as immuno-compromised people or those with other underlying health conditions, are more susceptible than others to contracting the virus.
Exposure to the virus can be controlled through the use of protective measures in clinics and hospitals, at community gatherings, or at home.

4. What are typical signs and symptoms of infection?
Sudden onset of fever, intense weakness, muscle pain, headache and sore throat are typical signs and symptoms. This is followed by vomiting, diarrhoea, rash, impaired kidney and liver function, and in some cases, both internal and external bleeding.
Laboratory findings include low white blood cell and platelet counts, and elevated liver enzymes.
The incubation period, or the time interval from infection to onset of symptoms, is from 2 to 21 days. The patients become contagious once they begin to show symptoms. They are not contagious during the incubation period.
Ebola virus disease infections can only be confirmed through laboratory testing.

5. When should someone seek medical care?
If a person has been in an area known to have Ebola virus disease or in contact with a person known or suspected to have Ebola and they begin to have symptoms, they should seek medical care immediately.
Any cases of persons who are suspected to have the disease should be reported to the nearest health unit without delay. Prompt medical care is essential to improving the rate of survival from the disease. It is also important to control spread of the disease and infection control procedures need to be started immediately.

6. What is the treatment?
Severely ill patients require intensive supportive care. They are frequently dehydrated and need intravenous fluids or oral rehydration with solutions that contain electrolytes. There is currently no specific treatment to cure the disease.
Some patients will recover with the appropriate medical care.
To help control further spread of the virus, people that are suspected or confirmed to have the disease should be isolated from other patients and treated by health workers using strict infection control precautions.

7. What can I do? Can it be prevented? Is there a vaccine?
Currently, there is no licensed medicine or vaccine for Ebola virus disease, but several products are under development.
Ways to prevent infection and transmission
While initial cases of Ebola virus disease are contracted by handling infected animals or carcasses, secondary cases occur by direct contact with the bodily fluids of an ill person, either through unsafe case management or unsafe burial practices. During this outbreak, most of the disease has spread through human-to-human transmission. Several steps can be taken to help in preventing infection and limiting or stopping transmission.

  • Understand the nature of the disease, how it is transmitted, and how to prevent it from spreading further. (For additional information, please see the previous questions about Ebola virus disease in this FAQ.)
  • Listen to and follow directives issued by your country's respective Ministry of Health.
  • If you suspect someone close to you or in your community of having Ebola virus disease, encourage and support them in seeking appropriate medical treatment in a health-care facility.
  • If you choose to care for an ill person in your home, notify public health officials of your intentions so they can train you and provide appropriate gloves and personal protective equipment (PPE) (gloves, impermeable gown, boots/closed shoes with overshoes, mask and eye protection for splashes), as well as instructions as a reminder on how to properly care for the patient, protect yourself and your family, and properly dispose of the PPE after use. N.B. WHO does not recommend home care and strongly advises individuals and their family members to seek professional care in a treatment centre.
  • When visiting patients in the hospital or caring for someone at home, hand washing with soap and water is recommended after touching a patient, being in contact with their bodily fluids, or touching his/her surroundings.
  • People who have died from Ebola should only be handled using appropriate protective equipment and should be buried immediately by public health professionals who are trained in safe burial procedures.

Additionally, individuals should reduce contact with high-risk infected animals (i.e. fruit bats, monkeys or apes) in the affected rainforest areas. If you suspect an animal is infected, do not handle it. Animal products (blood and meat) should be thoroughly cooked before eating.

8. What about health workers? How should they protect themselves while caring for patients?
Health workers treating patients with suspected or confirmed illness are at higher risk of infection than other groups. During an outbreak a number of important actions will reduce or stop the spread of the virus and protect health workers and others in the health-care setting. These actions are called "standard and other additional precautions" and are evidence-based recommendations known to prevent the spread of infections. The following questions and answers describe the precautions in detail.
Should patients with suspected or confirmed Ebola virus be separated from other patients?
Isolating patients with suspected or confirmed Ebola virus disease in single isolation rooms is recommended. Where isolation rooms are not available, it is important to assign designated areas, separate from other patients, for suspected and confirmed cases. In these designated areas, suspect and confirmed cases should also be separate. Access to these areas should be restricted, needed equipment should be dedicated strictly to suspected and confirmed EVD treatment areas, and clinical and non-clinical personnel should be exclusively assigned to isolation rooms and dedicated areas.
Are visitors allowed in areas where patients suspected or confirmed Ebola virus disease are admitted?
Stopping visitor access to patients infected with EVD is preferred. If this is not possible, access should be given only to those individuals who are necessary for the patient's well-being and care, such as a child's parent.
Is protective equipment required when caring for these patients?

  • In addition to standard health-care precautions, health-care workers should strictly apply recommended infection control measures to avoid exposure to infected blood, fluids, or contaminated environments or objects – such as a patient's soiled linen or used needles.
  • All visitors and health-care workers should rigorously use what is known as personal protective equipment (PPE). PPE should include at least: gloves, an impermeable gown, boots/closed shoes with overshoes, a mask, and eye protection for splashes (goggles or face shields).

Is hand hygiene important?
Hand hygiene is essential and should be performed:

  • before donning gloves and wearing PPE on entry to the isolation room/area;
  • before any clean or aseptic procedures is being performed on a patient;
  • after any exposure risk or actual exposure with a patient's blood or body fluids;
  • after touching (even potentially) contaminated surfaces, items, or equipment in the patient's surroundings; and
  • after removal of PPE, upon leaving the isolation area.

It is important to note that neglecting to perform hand hygiene after removing PPE will reduce or negate any benefits of the PPE.
Either an alcohol-based hand rub or soap and running water can be used for hand hygiene, applying the correct technique recommended by WHO. It is important to always perform hand hygiene with soap and running water when hands are visibly soiled. Alcohol-based hand rubs should be made available at every point of care (at the entrance and within the isolation rooms and areas); running water, soap, and single use towels should also be always available.
What other precautions are necessary in the health-care setting?
Other key precautions are safe injection and phlebotomy procedures, including safe management of sharps, regular and rigorous environmental cleaning, decontamination of surfaces and equipment, and management of soiled linen and of waste.
In addition, it is important to ensure safe processing of laboratory samples from suspected or confirmed patients with EDV and safe handling of dead bodies or human remains for post-mortem examination and burial preparation. Any health-care workers and other professionals undertaking these tasks in connection with suspected or confirmed patients with Ebola virus disease should wear appropriate PPE and follow precautions and procedures recommended by WHO.

9. What about rumours that some foods can prevent or treat the infection?
WHO strongly recommends that people seek credible health advice about Ebola virus disease from their public health authority.
While there is no specific drug against Ebola, the best treatment is intensive supportive treatment provided in the hospital by health workers using strict infection control procedures. The infection can be controlled through recommended protective measures.

10. How does WHO protect health during outbreaks?
WHO provides technical advice to countries and communities to prepare for and respond to Ebola outbreaks.
WHO actions include:

  • disease surveillance and information-sharing across regions to watch for outbreaks;
  • technical assistance to investigate and contain health threats when they occur – such as on-site help to identify sick people and track disease patterns;
  • advice on prevention and treatment options;
  • deployments of experts and the distribution of health supplies (such as personal protection gear for health workers) when they are requested by the country;
  • communications to raise awareness of the nature of the disease and protective health measures to control transmission of the virus; and
  • activation of regional and global networks of experts to provide assistance, if requested, and mitigate potential international health effects and disruptions of travel and trade.

11. During an outbreak, numbers of cases reported by health officials can go up and down? Why?
During an Ebola outbreak, the affected country's public health authority reports its disease case numbers and deaths. Figures can change daily. Case numbers reflect both suspected cases and laboratory-confirmed cases of Ebola. Sometimes numbers of suspected and confirmed cases are reported together. Sometimes they are reported separately. Thus, numbers can shift between suspected and confirmed cases.
Analyzing case data trends, over time, and with additional information, is generally more helpful to assess the public health situation and determine the appropriate response.

12. Is it safe to travel during an outbreak? What is WHO's travel advice?
During an outbreak, WHO reviews the public health situation regularly and recommends any travel or trade restrictions, if necessary, and may inform national authorities to implement it. WHO is currently reviewing its recommendations for travel and expects to issue advice in the coming days.
While travellers should always be vigilant with regard to their health and those around them, the risk of infection for travellers is very low since person-to-person transmission results from direct contact with the body fluids or secretions of an infected patient.
Is it safe to travel with persons who have Ebola?
As with any illness or disease, it is always possible that a person who has been exposed to Ebola virus may choose to travel. If the individual has not developed symptoms (see FAQ #4), they cannot transmit EVD to those around them. If the individual does have symptoms, they should seek immediate medical attention at the first sign they are feeling unwell. This may require either notifying the flight crew or ship crew or, upon arrival at a destination, seeking immediate medical attention. Travellers who show initial symptoms of EVD should be isolated to prevent further transmission. Although the risk to fellow travellers in such a situation is very low, contact tracing is recommended under these circumstances.
Is it safe to travel to West Africa on business or to visit family and friends?
The risk of a tourist or businessman/woman becoming infected with Ebola virus during a visit to the affected areas and developing disease after returning is extremely low, even if the visit included travel to the local areas from which primary cases have been reported. Transmission requires direct contact with blood, secretions, organs or other body fluids of infected living or dead persons or animal, all of which are unlikely exposures for the average traveller. In any event, tourists are advised to avoid all such contacts.
If you are visiting family or friends in the affected areas, the risk is similarly low, unless you have direct physical contact with a person who is ill or who has died. If this is the case, it is important to notify public health authorities and engage in contact tracing. Contact tracing is used to confirm you have not been exposed to EVD and to prevent further spread of the disease through monitoring.
WHO's general travel advice

  • Travelers should avoid all contact with infected patients.
  • Health workers traveling to affected areas should strictly follow WHO-recommended infection control guidance.
  • Anyone who has stayed in areas where cases were recently reported should be aware of the symptoms of infection and seek medical attention at the first sign of illness.
  • Clinicians caring for travelers returning from affected areas with compatible symptoms are advised to consider the possibility of Ebola virus disease.

For additional travel advice, please read the Travel and transport risk assessment: Recommendations for public health authorities and transport sector at http://who.int/ith/updates/20140421/en/

Health Research Paper Learning Goal:

The American Psychological Association (APA) - PDF 777 KB

As class requirements, students will be able to conduct intensive research in primary and secondary sources, and to complete a major research paper on an original topic.

Objectives:

  1. Conduct original research in published or unpublished primary sources
  2. Develop, under supervision, a substantial research paper
  3. Engage in an ongoing process of writing and revision
  4. Report orally on research and written work
  5. Emphasize research as an on-going process of discovery and growth, encouraging students to see research and inquiry as activities central to daily life. Teach students to conduct research and to critically evaluate the quality of sources.

body:
Going Once, Going Twice... Become an Auctioneer

Twenty years ago, Dick Henry was running a gas station. Now, he's hosting benefit auctions for organizations like the Berks County Humane Society and the Delaware Valley Golden Retriever Rescue.

Dick's career path has taken many twists and turns since his days at the gas station. The latest twist landed him in the Auctioneering Certification Program at Reading Area Community College.

While working in real estate, Dick attended a business brokerage seminar and was impressed with the presenter's public speaking skills.

"I asked him where he learned public speaking," Dick recalled. "He said, 'You're never going to believe this, but I became an auctioneer.'"

Dick was more than familiar with the auctioneering concept thanks to many weekends with his dad.

"My dad was an auction junkie, and I would always go with him," said Dick. "In the car business I went to a lot, and I always enjoyed the chant and the interaction, but I never had the desire."

When he realized it would enhance his public speaking skills, Dick checked out RACC's program and enrolled in 2004.

"You really don't know what to expect when you start," he said. "The one thing you think about when it comes to auctioneering is the chant and being able to call bids. Being a successful auctioneer is so much more than that."

While the program teaches the chanting, the curriculum also includes procurement and appraisal of personal property and real estate, laws and regulations, and preparation for auctions.

"It's a lot of hard work, cramming a lot of education into your brain for 10 weeks," said Dick, who has been teaching the program for two years. "I've always had happy students who enjoy the interaction with each other."

To finish the program, students are also required to participate in a practicum, where they gain hands-on experience with a licensed auctioneer. Whether it is clerking, keeping records or actually selling items, students must complete a minimum of 60 hours.

After completing RACC's program, Dick went for specialty training for benefit auctions through the National Auctioneers Association. He has since hosted auctions for the American Red Cross, the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, the RACC Scholarship Fund, and numerous churches and civic organizations.

"You really get addicted to it, but you also realize that you are there to do a job," he said.

The next session of the College's auctioneering program starts March 11, 2013. To help students with the cost, two scholarships have been established by an anonymous benefactor in Dick Henry's name.
title: The Path to Auctioneering
