The licensed electronic resources made available by The Yocum Library are for research, instruction, and related activities of current Reading Area Community College faculty, staff, students and other authorized users. U.S. Copyright Law (including the protections of “fair use”) and contractual license agreements govern the access, use, and reproduction of these resources. In general, authorized users may access such resources for noncommercial, educational, scholarly and research purposes. Prohibited actions generally include:

  • Sharing of passwords or authorized access codes. Sharing an access password with unauthorized users is a violation of the library’s license agreement. Non-affiliated users may, however, access most online library resources from computer terminals in the library.
  • Large-scale systematic downloading of articles or other information. Downloading entire issues of electronic journals, or attempting to create large databases from bibliographic files, is generally prohibited by publisher license agreements. Systematic downloading of content— manually or with specialized software— is detectable by publishers and traceable to specific computer addresses.
  • Modification of data or images from the resources. For example, images from the AMICO Library may not be edited or modified when copies of works are mounted locally.
  • Posting copyrighted materials on a publicly accessible web site
  • Resale or commercial exploitation of licensed information
  • Sharing proprietary or client software connected to information resources, such as that used to analyze spatial data or search and retrieve texts, is also prohibited under the terms of academic licenses.

Engaging in actions intended to circumvent or defeat access control mechanisms of the library or information provider may result in revocation of library privileges and other campus measures.

1 / 2004
title: Policies for Library Use of Licensed Resources

body:
The Yocum Library endorses the Interlibrary Loan Code for the United States.

Requests must be submitted online using the Interlibrary Loan Request Form.

Interlibrary Loans Originated by The Yocum Library

An interlibrary loan (ILL) is a request for a cataloged item that is owned by a library outside of The Yocum Library or the Advanced Library Information Network (ALIN) of Berks County. A request for a cataloged item that is available through the ALIN network is an intralibrary loan request and is processed using the ALIN “Hold” procedure although a request for a periodical article that is available within the ALIN network is considered an interlibrary loan..

The Yocum Library's mission provides the foundation for its provision of interlibrary loan services. Due to the high costs involved in the interlibrary loan process, this service is provided only to members of the RACC community – RACC students, staff, faculty, trustees, and alumni. Other library patrons should be referred to their public, college, or corporate libraries to obtain interlibrary loan services.

Members of the RACC community who are eligible for interlibrary loan services must have current library cards and no blocks, fines, charges, or overdue items on their library accounts. A library patron, who does not pick up an interlibrary loan item after notification of its receipt by The Yocum Library, will have a message placed on his/her library account; three or more such messages will block the patron from making more interlibrary loan requests from The Yocum Library. The Yocum Library reserves the right to deny interlibrary loan services to anyone who has not complied with the interlibrary loan policies and procedures in the past.

Because of the delay involved in obtaining interlibrary loan materials, an interlibrary loan request should be the product of a session with a librarian, so that the patron is first provided with as much information as possible from The Yocum Library's resources.

The Yocum Library reserves the right to refuse a request which violates local, state, or federal laws, such as, but not limited to, copyright violations.

Borrowing Costs for RACC Library Patrons

Internal costs of interlibrary loan transactions are part of the library budget. Any additional charge that is set by the lending library is to be paid by the library patron who originates the request.

Because of the serious obligation to adhere to all guidelines and rules set by the lending library, interlibrary loan items must be returned to The Yocum Library by the due date. A renewal of an interlibrary loan item must be requested one week prior to the due date although there is no guarantee that the lending library will renew the item.

Contact the Head of Interlibrary Loan of The Yocum Library or email the request to library@racc.edu

A patron who fails to return an interlibrary loan item by the due date will have a message placed on his/her library account; three or more such messages will block the patron from making more interlibrary loan requests from The Yocum Library.
Library patrons, who do not return interlibrary loan materials to The Yocum Library will be responsible for all charges and expenses that are levied by the lending library..

Interlibrary Loans Requested By Other Libraries

The Yocum Library accepts interlibrary loan (ILL) requests from organized libraries in the United States and its territories and from international libraries that provide proof of physical location. Requests are accepted by OCLC, by mail, by phone, by fax, or by e-mail.

The Yocum Library reserves the right to refuse a request that violates local, state, or federal laws, such as, but not limited to copyright violations.

Materials are lent to other libraries regardless of format. Availability of items depends on the need for the material by the patrons of The Yocum Library. Photocopies of periodical articles that are sent as an ILL request need not be returned by the requesting library. In most cases, materials on reserve or in reference cannot be loaned. The Director of Library Services may approve loan of a reserve or reference item. Items are lent for 4 weeks. Renewals must be requested one week before the item is due back to The Yocum Library.

Borrowing Costs for Libraries

The Yocum Library lends materials without charge to

  • Berks County libraries
  • Pennsylvania community college, Pennsylvania SSHE university, and Pennsylvania correctional institution libraries
  • Libraries who do not charge The Yocum Library for ILL requests

The Yocum Library lends materials at a fee to:

  • Libraries who charge The Yocum Library for ILL requests
  • For-profit institution libraries

Fees to be charged:

  • Returnable loan of item $10./request
  • Non-returnable loan of an item $10./item

Replacement Costs for Libraries

Borrowing libraries that do not return ILL items to The Yocum Library by the date set by the Head of Interlibrary Loan will be charged the replacement cost plus $10.00 processing charge per item. If an item cannot be replaced, a default cost that includes the processing charge will be billed to the borrowing library:
$20 for a mass market paperback
$30 for a trade paperback
$60 for a hardback book
$40 for a feature film in DVD or VHS formats
$200 for a documentary film
$30 for a sound recording
$35 for an art print
$20 for a map
title: Interlibrary Loan Policies

body:
The Yocum Library has several rooms that can be used by RACC students, staff, and faculty. Classrooms in the Humanities Center of The Yocum Library building are reserved through the office of the Vice President of Academic Affairs and the 4th floor of the library is reserved through the Office of the President.

The Director of Library Services administers the public use of Rooms Y103 and Y301(The Tower Room). These rooms can be used by RACC students, staff, and faculty for educational, cultural, intellectual, or charitable activities. Public areas of The Yocum Library cannot be used for meetings.

RACC Community

RACC students, staff, and faculty can reserve Rooms Y103 and Y301 (The Tower Room) by submitting the Yocum Library Room Reservation Form. Requests must be made 7 days in advance. Blocks of time can be reserved in these rooms in compliance with the following policies:

  • Rooms cannot be reserved for individual use.
  • Groups larger than 12 cannot be accommodated in the Library.
  • Groups can reserve a room for no more than 3 hours and for no more than 2 times a week.
  • Groups must cancel a room reservation if it is no longer needed. If groups do not arrive to use rooms within 15 minutes of scheduled use time, the rooms are reopened to public use.
  • No admission can be charged.
  • Groups are responsible for any damage to the room during its use.
  • Additions to or alterations of equipment, systems, or walls, flooring, furniture, etc., are not allowed.
  • Meetings may not use the wording at The Yocum Library in any advertisement unless permission has been granted by the Director of Library Services.
  • The Yocum Library reserves the right to cancel a reservation if the space is needed by the College.
  • Requests are accepted for one term only.
title: Yocum Library Room Use Policies

body:
Prior Learning Assessment (PLA) is a way for many adult learners to gain college credit for their life and professional knowledge. If a student can demonstrate that his or her knowledge and skills are current and comparable to what the college-educated student knows, RACC may award equal credit.

The most common way that prospective students demonstrate prior learning is through taking exams such as Advanced Placement, CLEP, DANTES/CLEP and Credit by Exam.

A portfolio is another method of requesting assessment of your knowledge as equivalent to a specific course or courses. Assessments are done for students who have formally applied to RACC and are actively pursuing a degree at the college.

Any credit received through prior learning assessments are articulated credits that may be used toward an associate degree earned at RACC. A candidate for graduation must have earned at least 15 of his/her total credit hours through classwork.

The Assessment Coordinator will assist a student through the portfolio development and assessment process.

What items can be included in a portfolio?

  • Past and current full- or part-time jobs
  • Military service
  • Organizational memberships
  • Independent reading and concentrated studies
  • Training programs, certificates, and/or in-service courses through employment and community service
  • All personal development, community service and travel
  • Any art, writing or musical pursuits

Remember to consider all the types of experiences that may draw directly to college-level courses which can describe the general knowledge you have accumulated throughout your life.

What are the steps for developing a portfolio for assessment?

  1. Apply to the College.
  2. Make an appointment to meet with the Assessment Coordinator to discuss goals, the process and possible courses for which portfolios may be developed.
  3. Collect any evidence of prior learning, including industry certificates, certificates of merit or coursework plans.
  4. Follow up with a second appointment with the Assessment Coordinator to evaluate resume and reaffirm course(s) for which you want to produce a portfolio.
  5. Develop portfolio following guidelines and advice of Assessment Coordinator.
  6. Submit portfolio to Assessment Coordinator in Berks Hall 211. Assessment of portfolio can take up to 30 days.
  7. Pay the Cashier’s Office any necessary fees.
  8. Make an appointment to review portfolio assessment results.

Remember you are not alone in developing your portfolio; however, you will need to take time to track down a number of documents and write about your experience as it applies to a course competency.

Does the portfolio have a required format and length?

Portfolios vary tremendously in size and style. However, for the purpose of continuity, RACC requires an organized binder with the following sections:

  • A statement of the person’s goals, both personal and academic
  • Resume
  • Documentation
  • Cross reference of course competencies and documentation
  • Statement of accuracy of portfolio contents

What is most important about your portfolio is your ability to clearly convey, in both oral and written form, your prior knowledge. Working closely with the Assessment Coordinator will help you through this process. RACC will work with you on helping to turn your prior learning into college credit.

For more information, contact the Director of Academic Partnerships, Jodi Corbett, jcorbett@racc.edu, 610-607-6219.
title: Prior Learning Assessment

Two years ago, life for Rich Fasnacht was crumbling around - his family, home and career. An assistant production manager at a Berks County company, he was laid off and looking for a new direction.

Rich talked to friends, knocked on doors, and reached out to businesses to find anything to get his life back on track. At the end of the search, he found RACC and its tuition waiver policy for recently laid-off employees in Berks County.

In December 2009, Rich enrolled at RACC in the mechatronics associate degree program, offered through the Schmidt Training and Technology Center (STTC).

"The biggest challenge was regrouping and getting my focus back," said Rich, a native of Schuylkill County. "I was traveling down this road and then a curve ball was thrown at me that I wasn't expecting."

It was the staff and students alike at the STTC that offered Rich, 36, a support system and advice to help him regain the focus he needed to succeed.

"Everybody has a story," said Rich, who was the first in his family to go to college in 1995. "They really help you and tell you that you can do this. That was really the difference for me."

Rich was not a stranger to college, as he already earned an associate degree in machines trade technology from Thaddeus Stevens College of Technology.

"I wanted to use the foundation I already had and build on that," he said. "It was going to be an accumulation of knowledge."

Rich is currently taking Advanced Manufacturing Integrated Systems Technology (AMIST) courses, along with Math and English Composition. He is on pace to earn his degree in 2013.

In addition to taking classes, Rich also works as an instructor aid at the STTC, helping with the mechanical and electrical labs. In fact, earlier this school year, he received the Schmidt Technology Teaching Scholarship, which is awarded to a student interested in teaching in the technology field.

"I have to learn by application and get my hands on something," he said. "I memorize things quicker by showing them to other people, so they benefit and I benefit."
title: Picking Up the Pieces

PUBLIC ACCESS

The Yocum Library is the Library of Reading Area Community College (RACC).  Although RACC students, staff, and faculty are the focus of the Library's resources and services, the Library is open to the public.

Any patron over 18 years of age may use the Library. However, children under 18 who are not RACC students or participating in a RACC-sponsored event must be accompanied by an adult, who is at least 18 years old and responsible for the child at all times. Proof of age is required.  Children under 18 must be under direct adult supervision of a caregiver who is able to attend to the child's safety and ensure appropriate behavior.  The supervising adult is responsible for the behavior and safety of minors.  Library staff does not have custodial responsibility and cannot assume liability for unattended children.  If a child is found unattended in the Library, staff will attempt to locate the child's parent/guardian. If staff cannot locate a parent/guardian, RACC Security will be notified as well as police and children services if necessary.  Adults who cannot care for themselves must be monitored by their caregivers.

The Library honors all Berks County public libraries consortium Library cards (adult and children), but the Yocum Library only issues adult Library cards to community members who have a valid PA ID and proof of current address.

The Library's computers are available only to RACC trustees, faculty, staff, students, and alumni. There is a WiFi network in the Library that can be used with a non-RACC patron's own laptop computer to access the Internet. 

The Library staff reserves the right to remove any patron whose behavior violates the Library’s Standards of Behavior Policy.

ACTIVITY ZONES

While the Yocum Library staff wants to provide an environment that is friendly and comfortable for our patrons, we must emphasize that the Library is a center for learning.  Some people need a quiet place to learn while others learn best through group collaboration.  It is also a center for teaching because both teaching and librarian faculty instruct individuals and groups in the use of Library resources and services.  In order to create an environment that serves both types of learners while also accommodating the Library’s teaching function, we have divided the Library into two distinct activity zones.  Each zone has a different noise level expectation.

The Quiet Study Zone is intended to serve individual students who need to concentrate.  In this zone NO talking is permitted.  Headphones that are able to block all sound transmission must be used when listening to audio on computers or other equipment.   The 3rd and 4th floors are the Quiet Study Zones in the Library.  Nevertheless, some noise is to be expected in this zone during special events on the 4th floor.

The Active Learning Zone is intended for instructional and/or collaborative learning experiences.  In this zone moderate-level talking is expected and quiet cell phone conversations are permitted.  Headphones that are able to block all sound transmission must be used when listening to audio on computers or other equipment.  The 2nd floor is the Active Learning Zone.

Patrons who do not conform to the acceptable noise level of the Library zone will be asked to modify their behavior or move to a more appropriate area.  Patrons who do not agree to conform to the acceptable noise level of the Library zone or agree to use another area of the Library will be asked to leave the Library.

Please contact a Library staff member if you have a concern about noise levels at a specific time. 

EXPECTED BEHAVIORS

  • Patrons shall follow all RACC policies and federal, state, or local laws, including, but not limited to, the RACC Student Bill of Rights (RACC students only), RACC Computer Usage Policy which is posted on the Library’s website and near the entrance of the Library, and the Academic Honesty Policy; Federal laws on copyright infringement and peer-to-peer file sharing; and Pennsylvania laws on mutilating and stealing Library materials such as the Pennsylvania Library Theft Act which is posted on the Library’s website and information kiosk at the entrance of the Library.
  • Library patrons shall respect the rights of all other patrons and staff at all times. Patrons are expected to conduct themselves in a manner that enables patrons and Library staff to accomplish their intended Library tasks in a safe, civil, and orderly atmosphere. Patrons are urged to report disruptive behavior to Library staff.  Staff will take appropriate action when patron behavior causes disruption in the delivery of services. 
  • Patrons display behaviors appropriate to the Activity Zone that they are in.
  • Patrons must wear appropriate and complete dress, including shirt and footwear, at all times.  Clothing and accessories with offensive language, racial comments or slurs, or other inappropriate language, logos and/or pictures are unacceptable dress and if worn, the Library patron will be asked to leave the Library.
  • Patrons are responsible for their own property and should not leave personal items unattended.  Unattended items may be subject to inspection and/or removal.
  • If the security gates sound an alarm as a patron exits, the patron must return to the Service Desk to verify that the materials were handled properly by the staff. All briefcases, handbags, backpacks, duffle bags, overcoats, shopping bags, luggage, and other packages may be subject to inspection by Library or Security staff.
  • Patrons must leave the Library at the designated closing times or upon request from Library staff or RACC Security staff.  If the Library’s emergency systems are activated, patrons must follow all staff directions and instructions.

UNACCEPTABLE BEHAVIORS

Unacceptable behaviors are those that, by the assessment of the Library staff, interfere with the use of the Library by other patrons, create a risk of injury to other patrons and/or Library staff, interfere with the work of Library staff, or create a risk of damage to Library property.  The Library reserves the right to interpret this standard, to apply it, and to change it as necessary. This is not an exhaustive list; unacceptable behaviors include, but are not limited, to:

  • Harassing or discriminatory behavior based on race, color, religion, gender, age, national origin, veteran status, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, or any other status protected by law.
  • Any type of behavior that detracts from the teaching/learning process such as running, throwing objects; yelling; climbing on furniture; following patrons or staff throughout the Library; annoying fellow patrons by talking to them while they are trying to read, study or contemplate; abusing, verbally harassing or intimidating patrons or staff; use of profanity, abusive or threatening language; use of threatening gestures or unwanted physical contact.
  • Intentionally damaging, destroying, or stealing any property that belongs to the Library, a staff member, or a patron.
  • Possession or consumption of alcohol except at authorized RACC functions.
  • Possession or consumption of illegal drugs, narcotics, or controlled substances.
  • Consumption of tobacco products.
  • Inappropriate sexual behavior including engaging in lewd or lascivious behavior, solicitation, sexual harassment, indecent exposure and/or voyeurism.
  • Possession of weapons of any kind, except by authorized RACC staff or law enforcement officers.
  • Roller blading, roller skating, or skate boarding on Library premises.
  • Bringing animals into the Library except those that are part of a RACC program or are service animals.
  • Distributing, posting, or placing on Library property any printed materials except through authorized RACC procedures.
  • Selling or soliciting in the Library unless authorized by the RACC administration such as for RACC clubs.
  • Entering areas marked "Library Staff Only” or using Library staff telephones or other staff equipment without permission.
  • Inappropriately or excessively using the restrooms including bathing, shaving, or clothes washing.
  • Sleeping in the Library.
  • Viewing on computer screens images that are not appropriate for a public and open environment and that create a hostile or offensive environment.
  • Using emergency exits or setting off fire, elevator, and/or exit door alarms when no emergency exists.
  • Blocking walkways, exits, or entrances with electrical cords or personal belongings.

SANCTIONS

  • RACC students, faculty, and staff are liable to the sanctions as defined in existing RACC policies.  These sanctions may include warnings, immediate removal from the Library by Security staff, and/or permanent banning from the Library.  Appeals may be made following established RACC policies.
  • Non-RACC patrons who violate The Yocum Library’s Standards of Behavior Policy may receive sanctions that include a warning, immediate removal from the Library by Security staff, permanent banning from the RACC campus, and/or criminal prosecution if the conduct constitutes a violation of local, state or federal law.

June 2013
title: The Yocum Library Standards of Behavior Policy

body:
Commitment to service to its patrons provides the foundation for The Yocum Library's provision of reference services. Reference services are provided to students, staff, and faculty of Reading Area Community College as well as to individuals and institutions who request these services. Although members of the RACC community have priority, reference service is provided as quickly as possible for non-college patrons and institutions.

Reference services are provided in person, by telephone, by mail, by fax, or by e-mail. If possible, simple reference questions received by telephone are answered while the patron is on the line. However, for questions requiring more in-depth research, the library staff will contact the patron as soon as possible. Results may also be sent directly to the patron by mail, by fax, or by e-mail. More complex searches may require the recommendation that the patron visit the library in person.

The Yocum Library reserves the right to refuse requests which violate local, state, or federal law, such as, but not limited to, requests which are violations of copyright, pornography, sexual harassment, or privacy laws. The library staff is not accountable for the validity of published information or for uses to which information may be put by patrons. Moreover, the library staff does not interpret the law, diagnose medical problems, or recommend materials or companies for purchase or hire. The library staff does not provide computer program instruction.

If the resources of The Yocum Library cannot satisfy the patron's request, the library staff will contact other libraries or resource centers to attempt to discover a source. If the patron needs to visit another facility to acquire the needed information, the library staff will provide guidance in the use of the recommended facility.

The level of the reference request determines which library staff member should provide service. All library staff members answer directional questions: location of library features - circulation desk, reference desk, computer catalogs, Internet workstations, photocopiers, displays, collections, offices, study rooms, testing center, bathrooms, etc. Student staff members answer directional questions only.

In addition to directional questions, library assistants assist patrons in the basic use of computer catalogs, Internet workstations, audio-visual equipment, photocopiers, retrieval of library materials, and explanations of library policies and procedures.

In addition to the above services library paraprofessionals provide basic reference services to patrons. They conduct introductory reference interviews and determine the level of the reference request. They provide reference services or refer the patron to the reference librarian if they determine that more help is required. They assist the patron in computer catalog features, Internet search strategies, and basic reference sources. They provide instruction in basic library search techniques.

Reference librarians provide the highest level of reference service. Patrons should interface with the reference librarian before pursuing other sources including interlibrary loan. They recommend patrons to other facilities for further research and instruct patrons in the effective use of those facilities. They provide in-depth library instruction. If a reference librarian is not available, the patron can schedule a meeting in person or by telephone.
title: The Yocum Library Reference Policies

    Phone:
    (610) 372-4721 x5454
    (800) 626-1665 x5454

    Email: jlawlor@racc.edu or jmlawlor@comcast.net

    For the Teacher

    This unit is designed to teach students to think about land usage over time with consideration of historical changes.  The date range is from 1737 to 1998 and the unit employs actual working maps of the river front area of Reading, Pennsylvania.   Additionally, historical photographs have been incorporated.  The most recent image is a contemporary photograph of the Penn Street Bridge.

    Activities: Students will create a map that shows changes over time. Students will create a list of changes and occupations that they discover through the use of the unit. The class will then discuss and compare findings.

    Grading: Maps and lists can be submitted for grading purposes.

    Back
title: John M. Lawlor, Jr.

    Email: jlawlor@racc.edu or jmlawlor@comcast.net

    Philadelphia and Reading Railway Company

    1917 Interstate Commerce Commission Valuation Map

    Front and Penn Street Area

    In 1917 all railroads were required to account for everything they owned. They had to supply a count, description, and value for each and every item. In addition, real estate was inventoried through extremely detailed maps. These maps typically covered 50 foot per inch in scale and provide valuable information, not just about the railroad holdings, but about adjacent properties as well.


    ICC Valuation, P&RR, Map Segment V26P/5. June 30, 1917
    National Archives and Records Administration, Cartography Branch.
    Click on the map to retrieve a larger image

    Questions:

    1. Locate the Penn Street Bridge.
    2. What is the orientation of the map (ie. the top of the map is what direction)?
    3. What do you suppose the lines on the Penn Street Bridge indicate?
    4. What do all the lines next to the river indicate?
    5. Actually, two railroads are shown on the map. What railroads are they?
    6. If this is 1917, what is the material used to construct the Penn Street Bridge (Clue?)
    7. What do all the little rectangles indicate below the railroad tracks? Can you find the tennis court?
    8. This map matches the orientation of which of the previous maps?
    9. Update your map with some of the changes using your blue pencil. (Note you will have to be selective because there are a lot of changes on this map. Just update the map with major changes.)

    Back

    What's in a Name?

    Compare the map inset below with the 1737 map to determine the following:

    1. What is the orientation of the map (which direction is at the top, right, left, and bottom)?
    2. For the four streets you identified on the 1737 map, what were they known as in 1825?
    3. Why do you suppose the names of some streets were changed?
    4. What is new on the 1825 map that did not exist in 1737? What has changed? What does this tell you about the development of the city? Update your hand drawn map with the green pencil.
    5. Click here for a Penn Street sights from after 1815.

    Canal Map Collection, Reading Area Community College.

    Email: jlawlor@racc.edu or jmlawlor@comcast.net

    Early Reading, Pennsylvania

    Urban Design Issues and Outcomes


    Reading Eagle, June 28, 1925.


    Some Questions/Activities

    1. Find a river on the map. What is its name? Who lived along the river before the settlers came?
    2. In addition to supplying water for drinking and irrigation, how else do you suppose the river affected the early development of this city? What impact do you suppose the people had on the river?
    3. How did people get to the west side of the river?
    4. Notice the squares in the center of the map? What do the squares indicate?; What effects may this city design have on future generations?
    5. Four streets are labeled on the map. What are they? Why do they look important?
    6. What do you think the sentence "Fenced and occupied by one Brown on Tolerance" means?
    7. How typical do you think the characteristics of this early Pennsylvania city are?
    8. Make a hand drawn sketch of this map, concentrating on the area between King Street and the river. You will use it to determine changes. Use a black pencil and allow room for changes. Notate on your map key streets, the river, and any other features you consider important.
    9. If you were to found a city, what might that city look like? Could you draw a map of it?

    Back

    Questions:

    1. See if you can locate the Penn Street Bridge. What is the orientation of this map? What direction is at the top, bottom, left and right?
    2. After 1846, the canal entered the downtown Reading area south of the Penn Street Bridge. See if you can locate the canal on the map.
    3. Notice that there is another bridge indicated on the map. It crosses the river at the third "L" in Schuylkill River. What means of transportation probably used this bridge?
    4. Comparing this map with the 1737 map, what are the major changes the area next to the river has undergone?
    5. Notice the floodline of 1869 (it was drawn in on this 1860 map). How does that flood line compare with the floodline of tropical storm Agnes in 1972? (aerial photograph of the Agnes flood.)
    6. Update your map with the new information using your red pencil.

    Back

This course offers a basic comprehensive program review of the anatomy and physiology of the venous system, vein identification, criteria for vein and device selection, equipment, complications, documentation, legal aspects, and guidelines for infection control.

ZHEC-700-303 (7 credit hrs.) $185

April 12, 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.

Goal

Provide the professional nurse with the current knowledge in obtaining and maintaining peripheral venous access. Classroom competency will be obtained by completion of a test with a score of at least 80% and performance of a simulated peripheral IV insertion. Your employer is responsible for validating your bedside competency in performing a peripheral IV insertion in accordance with the institution/agency policies and procedures. Completion of evaluation form must be performed at the end of course to receive certificate.

Learning Objectives

At the conclusion of this program, the learner will be able to:

  • Identify the three layers of venous anatomy
  • Identify the superficial veins used for a peripheral venipuncture
  • List the factors considered in vein selection
  • Describe preventative and treatment measures for peripheral IV complications
  • Demonstrate the peripheral IV procedure

Target Audience

Registered or Licensed Practical Nurses

Tuition

$185 (includes program materials, lunch not provided.)

Contact Hours

All participants will receive a certificate for 7 contact hours from Reading Area Community College. Courses must be completed in entirety to receive certification of credits. This continuing nursing education activity was approved by the PA State Nurses Association, an accredited approver by the American Nurses Credentialing Center’s Commission on Accreditation.

Note: Due to the 1992 OSHA Occupational Exposure and Blood Borne Standards the practicum for this course will be performed on a model.

Presenter

Diane Price, RN, BSN, CRNI

Diane Price received her diploma from the Reading Hospital School of Nursing and her BSN from Pennsylvania State University. She received her intravenous certification over five years ago. Diane lectures to graduate nurses and experienced nurses on a continuing basis. Currently, she is employed as an intravenous nurse with 25 years of experience.

Course Schedule

8:30 AM Registration
8:30 AM–9:30 AM Anatomy and Physiology of the Venous System
9:30 AM–10:30 AM Techniques of IV Therapy
10:30 AM-10:45 AM Break
10:45 AM–11:15 AM IV Complications
11:15 AM–11:45 AM Legal Aspects
11:45 AM–12:30 PM Lunch
12:30 PM–1:00 PM Infection Control Guidelines
1:00 PM–2:00 PM Venipuncture Practicum
2:00 PM–2:45 PM Test
2:45 PM–3:00 PM Test Review
3:00 PM–4:30 PM Supervised Venipuncture Practicum

There is no conflict of interest demonstrated in the presentation or planning of this course by the presenter or planner.
title: IV Venipuncture Certification

body:
Eligible Borrowers

• Affiliated borrowers: All current students, faculty, and staff, trustees, and alumni of Reading Area Community College

• Non-affiliated borrowers: Non-RACC borrowers who have a Berks County Advanced Library Information Network (ALIN) library card.

Checkout Limits:

• Affiliated borrowers (students and alumni): 10 per print format (e.g., books, magazines, maps, art prints) + 3 per non-print format (e.g., music CDs / books on CDs/ DVDs, VHS tapes). Affiliated borrowers (students and alumni) may borrow only one “High Demand” item per format at a time.

• Affiliated borrowers (faculty, staff, and trustees): as needed for their classes and projects

• Non-affiliated borrowers: 10 books + 3 per non-print format (e.g., music CDs / books on CDs/ DVDs, VHS tapes). Non-affiliated borrowers may borrow only one “High Demand” item per format at a time.


Borrower's Responsibilities

• Borrowers agree to abide by The Yocum Library Policies.

• Borrowers are required to present their own valid library cards for checkout of material; library cards from other patrons cannot be used. A picture ID may be required in addition to a valid library card.

• RACC students, staff, and faculty must present proof of current RACC status for Library computer usage sticker.

• Borrowers are financially responsible for all materials charged out on their cards. Borrowers should report a lost or stolen card to library staff at once to minimize responsibility for its unauthorized use.

• Borrowers should note time and date that material is due. Overdue notices are not sent out. Notice of date due is communicated at the time of borrowing, is noted on the item, and is available in the patron’s online account.

Accessing Your Library Account

• All borrowers: Go to RACC's Library Catalog and click on "My Library Account."

Loan Periods

Materials are due on days when the library is open, including weekends, semester breaks, and other days when classes are not in session.

Renewal of Library Materials

• To renew items: Go to www.racc.edu > The Yocum Library > Online Catalog > My Account
OR Stop at the Circulation Desk on the 2nd floor of the library
OR call 610-607-6237 or 800-626-1665 ext. 6237

• If renewals are allowed on the item, borrowers can renew items ONE time. 
(Note: An item cannot be renewed if another patron has a hold on the item.)

Return of Library Materials

• Materials on regular loan may be returned to any ALIN library in Berks County. For a list of ALIN libraries see http://www.berks.lib.pa.us/libs.htm

• Reserve items including Museum Passes must be returned directly to The Yocum Library because of their short loan periods.

• RACC-initiated Interlibrary Loans must be returned to the Yocum Library only.

• If materials need to be returned by mail, contact the library for permission and mailing instructions.


Charges, Overdue Materials, Penalties, and Assessments

Replacement Library Cards:

• Affiliated borrowers: Contact The Yocum Library Circulation Desk

• Non-affiliated borrowers: $2 payable at The Yocum Library Circulation Desk

Regular Loans:

•Thirty days after the due date of an item with a 4 week loan period, the Library presumes the material is lost and charges the borrower the replacement cost of the item plus a $15 processing fee per item. Seven days after the due date of an item with a 1 week loan period, the Library presumes the material is lost and charges the borrower the replacement cost of the item plus a $15 processing fee per item. Note: Individual parts of some DVD sets such as television series or documentaries may not be available separately so that the replacement cost would be the cost of the entire season.

•One week after a Museum Pass’s due date, the Library presumes the pass is lost and charges the borrower the replacement cost plus a $15 processing fee.

•If the item is returned in usable condition within one month of the lost status date, all costs and fees are waived.  If the item is returned in usable condition more than a month after the lost status date, the replacement cost is waived but the borrower is responsible for the $15 per item processing fee.  

 

Sanctions

Unpaid fines and charges may result in one or more of the following actions:

• Affiliated borrowers cannot borrow RACC materials if they have overdue items, lost items, three or more Claimed Returned statuses, or charges in excess of $10.00 from an ALIN library.  They cannot borrow RACC items if they have RACC-initiated blocks on their patron records.  With special permission from the Assistant Dean of Library Services they may be able to borrow RACC course-related items from RACC for one semester.  RACC costs and fees not paid will be added to a RACC’s student account as a Library Hold.  RACC Library Holds may prevent students from registering for RACC classes or receiving RACC transcripts.

• Non-affiliated borrowers cannot borrow RACC materials if they have overdue items, lost items, three or more Claimed Returned statuses, or charges in excess of $10.00 from an ALIN library.  They cannot borrow RACC items if they have RACC-initiated blocks on their patron records.  Fees assessed against a non-affiliated borrower's account that are not paid within 60 days may be remanded to a collection agency. Additional fees will be charged by the College for this process.

• All borrowers: The Yocum Library may suspend borrowing privileges if a borrower does not pay accumulated fees and fines.  The Yocum Library reserves the right to initiate collection agency actions or legal proceedings to recover library materials.
title: The Yocum Library Circulation Policy

title: BLS Courses for Healthcare Professionals

body:
At the conclusion of this course, instructor candidates will be able to teach a BLS course using video and lesson maps that are part of the American Heart Association curriculum.

Course Dates

Course Meeting Time

All classes meet from 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM.

Course Location

Reading Area Community College - Schuylkill Hall Room 216

Course Prerequisites

  1. Have a current American Heart Association BLS Healthcare Provider Card.
  2. Be accepted by an American Heart Association Training Center.
  3. Contact RACC to register for the Instructor Course. Class size is limited.

Students must demonstrate proficiency in BLS skills during class. Practical skill check and written exam will be given during class. Student must be able to complete all BLS skills without prompting and achieve 90% or better on written exam to pass the course. Tuition will NOT be refunded if course is failed.

Tuition

$325 includes the practicum portion of testing and documented compliance. Card administered to demonstrate compliance.

If you have any questions regarding prerequisites, the AHA Essential course or other requirements, please contact Lisa Mauger-Kulp by phone at 610-607-6220 or by email at lmaugerkulp@racc.edu.

Registration

By Phone

Call 610-607-6235 or 610-607-6231 to register with a VISA, MasterCard, or Discover card.

title: Psi Beta Meetings & Activities

body:
Reading Area Community College inducted eight students into its newly-approved chapter of Psi Beta, a national honor society for psychology students at two-year colleges, during a special ceremony on May 10 at the College.

Andrew Baumeister first conceived the idea of a RACC chapter of Psi Beta during the 2012-13 academic year. He talked about the idea with Vince Orlando, a fellow psychology major, while the two were work-study students in the Advantage Program office. Although Andrew graduated last May, Vince picked up and ran with the cause, with the help and advising of Dr. David Brant.

There were seven meetings during this academic year where students who were interested in the club elected officers and created a constitution and by-laws for Student Government Association to approve them as a sanctioned campus activity.

"Every officer worked relentlessly to have the club sanctioned on RACC campus," said Melissa Lindbom, who is secretary of RACC's chapter of Psi Beta. "Though it was a struggle, we constantly worked together in order to achieve our goal. I can't thank them enough for their diligence and determination."

Kim Beadencup, the group's vice-president, graduated in December but returned for a few extra classes in the spring semester. "I felt in my heart that I needed to come back one more semester because I felt like I left unfinished business behind. I know that I will enjoy the benefits of being a PSI Beta member. However, my greater joy is the privilege I was given to have a part in leaving a legacy behind at RACC," said Kim.

Dr. Brant, who has been a full-time faculty member at RACC since 2001, has also been a clinician for more than 30 years. He also runs a limited private practice in Berks County.

"Dr. Brant was the glue that held the officers together," said Melissa. "His passion for psychology and education has been a true inspiration. I can only hope that Psi Beta will become as much of a positive aspect of RACC as possible. We all worked hard so that future RACC students are provided with the opportunity to join Psi Beta and prosper within it."

Service opportunities, networking and scholarships are the major benefits for students who join RACC's chapter of Psi Beta. Already during meetings this year, guest speakers have included Berks Connection Pre-Trial Services and alumni Chris O'Reilly who is the Relapse Unit Clinical Supervisor at Caron Treatment Centers. The club recently volunteered at a fundraiser breakfast for Berks Connection, a non-profit agency that assists individuals and families involved in the Berks County criminal and juvenile justice systems. Looking ahead for the coming year, Dr. Brant is coordinating RACC student involvement in the PA Psychological Association conference that will be in Harrisburg.

Rachel Lee, the current club treasurer, is one of those students who will be able to reap the Psi Beta rewards for the upcoming year. A psychology major, Rachel has been involved with the club since the first meeting when there were just four students. She was attracted to the idea of creating something permanent at RACC that would benefit all psychology students across time.

"Today, it truly amazes me to see how many students are talking about Psi Beta, attending the meetings, and are listening to the speakers we bring in. I can't wait for next year," Rachel said.

Interested students do not have to be psychology majors, but the chapter does require a 3.25 overall GPA and a 3.5 GPA in psychology classes.

Vince, who  also graduated this year, feels a sense of fulfillment and accomplishment. "This experience will go down in history at RACC. I do not believe that it will ever be forgotten by the students and advisors who worked so hard to make this dream a reality."
title: RACC Launches Psi Beta Chapter

body:
All full or part-time credit division students who are currently registered at RACC (regardless of major) and who meet all qualifications for membership listed below are eligible for membership in the College's Psi Beta Chapter.

  • You have completed a 100-level college Psychology course with a grade of B or higher.
  • You have completed a 200-level (or higher) Psychology course with a grade of B or higher.
  • You have a combined GPA of 3.50 or higher for all completed Psychology coursework.
  • You have completed 12 credits of college coursework with a cumulative college GPA of 3.25 or higher.
  • You are currently enrolled at RACC.
  • You have a sincere interest in psychology.
  • You have high personal standards of behavior and integrity and abide by RACC's Student Responsibilities and Academic Honesty Policies, as outlined in the Student Handbook.
  • You are registered with the national Psi Beta Office prior to induction or have submitted an application and are awaiting official approval.
  • You will pay a $50 one-time, lifetime fee to Psi Beta International.
  • You commit to fulfilling the duties of voting members (see below).

If you believe you qualify for membership in RACC Psi Beta and are interested in joining, please stop by a meeting, e-mail RACC Psi Beta at psibeta@racc.edu, or contact Psi Beta's advisor, Dr. David Brant at dbrant@racc.edu.

Voting Members

The duties of the Voting Members include:

  • You attend all meetings of Psi Beta in their entirety.*
  • You serve on committees voluntarily or by appointment, as necessary to help promote Psi Beta's mission.
  • You support Psi Beta Fundraisers.
  • You participate in a minimum of one (1) community service project per academic semester.
  • You vote on all organization business. (Please note that an affirmative vote implies support for the initiative and participation whenever possible.)
  • You maintain a minimum 3.25 overall GPA and a minimum 3.5 GPA in psychology.**

*If you cannot attend a meeting, you communicate to the President or Secretary that you are unable to attend at least 24 hours in advance of the meeting in order to be considered "excused."
If you accumulate two excused absences or one unexcused absence in a semester, you will forfeit your voting membership.

** If your overall GPA falls below a 3.25 or your psychology GPA falls below a 3.5, you will no longer be eligible to vote and will be deemed an inactive member, until such time that your GPA again meets the college's eligibility requirements. You will NOT immediately lose your Psi Beta Membership!

For more information, please reference our Chapter's Bylaws.
title: Psi Beta Membership Requirements

body:
In addition to the friendships, professional connections, research opportunities, and community service events, Psi Beta has much to offer its Members. The following are some of our favorite benefits that Psi Beta membership has offered us:

  • Members gain recognition for achieving the honor of membership. Among the entities that recognize Psi Beta membership: Psi Chi, APA, APS, psychology departments at colleges and universities, and employers.
  • Members gain eligibility to be student affiliate members in the American Psychological Association (APA) and the Association for Psychological Science (APS).
  • Members have the opportunity to attend and present at regional and national psychological association conferences. In addition, Psi Beta often offers special programming for members during these conferences.
  • Members can receive verification of membership throughout the member's lifetime.
  • Members have the opportunity to develop & hone leadership experience.
  • Members receive the opportunity to connect and be mentored by their Psychology professors, which can lead to strong personal references when considering transferring to 4-year institutions.
  • Eligibility for national awards, such as those listed here.
  • Eligibility for these different annual awards: Building Bonds, Chapter Excellence, Chapter Community service, Individual Community Service, College Life Award, and Faculty Advisor.
  • Publication of membership and activities in the nationally distributed Psi Beta Newsletter.
  • Ethnic minority students can participate in the annual Diversity Project mentoring program during the annual conference of the American Psychological Association.
  • Psi Beta membership meets one of the requirements for entrance at the GS-7 level (2 levels higher) in numerous occupations in Federal service.

For more information regarding the benefits of joining Psi Beta, stop by a meeting, e-mail RACC Psi Beta at psibeta@racc.edu, or read this article.
title: Psi Beta Membership Benefits

    Land Use and Urban Development

    Reading, Pennsylvania Example

    Maps--Click on the Year for a Map.

    1737      1825      1860      1917      1993

    For each year listed above there is a linked map or other images. Your task is to study the map and then answer the questions about each one.In most cases, a larger image is available if you "Click" on the image. This task will take some real detective work. Using the maps, photographs, artwork and clues, draw and update a map that shows how the land usage changed over time (1737-1998) and create a running list of changes such as streets, buildings, and anything else you can find. Finally, keep track of the occupations of people who worked along the river.

The Mechatronics Engineering Technology Program is one of the College's newest associate degree programs. The program uses an integrated approach to learning mechanics, electronics, control theory and computer science. Upon successful completion, students will be able to maintain, troubleshoot and repair highly sophisticated, automated systems - making them extremely valuable potential employees.

The mechatronics program is open to both traditional students looking to earn their degree, as well as current employees wishing to upgrade their skills by taking select courses as time permits.

 

For more information about RACC's mechatronics program, please contact Bonnie Spayd.

body:
Skilled machinists are always in demand and will be as long as there is a machine that is used to manufacture a product, assist in agriculture, construct homes and buildings, save time and energy, produce energy and to provide recreation.

Machine tool technicians produce precision parts using machine tools such as lathes, drill presses and milling machines. They set up and operate a wide variety of machine tools and have a thorough understanding of the working properties of various materials including metals, plastics and composites.

Using their skill with machine tools and knowledge of materials, machine tool technicians plan and carry out the operations needed to make machined products that meet precise specifications.

RACC offers both theoretical and hands-on training for machine tool technology that meet the needs of business and also fulfills the requirements for the Machine Tool Technology Apprenticeship Program.

Courses include:

  • Basic CNC Machine Operation
  • Introduction to Machining
  • Basic Machine Tools
  • Turning Technology Level 1
  • Milling Technology Level 1
  • CNC Programming
  • Blueprint Reading
  • Engineering Graphics
  • Turning Technology Level 2
  • Milling Technology Level 2
  • CNC Milling Level 1
  • CNC Milling Level 2
  • CAM Programming
  • Advanced CNC Turning
  • CNC Fixture Design
  • Grinding
  • Manufacturing Fundamentals

For more information, please contact Doug Keim, 610.372.4721, extension 5176 or dkeim@racc.edu

body:
Learn: Technical Math, Blueprint Reading, Mechanical and Electrical Fabrication, Production Assembly, Welding, Safety Practices & Regulations, Personal Protective Equipment, Communication Skills, Conflict Resolution and Teamwork.

Length of Program: 8 weeks.

At the completion of this program, you will be eligible to pursue a job as a Team Assembler or Machine Equipment Operator who work in the production of durable goods.

Also, you may continue to build upon your credentials in the Industrial Maintenance (AMIST 1) program or CNC Machine Operator program.

For more information, please contact Judy Vecchio or call 610-372-4721, ext. 5716.
title: Industrial Production Technician

body:
All three components of the AMIST program (mechanical, electrical and PLC) provide training in skills used in advanced manufacturing worksites today, from electrical control circuits to pneumatic and hydraulic troubleshooting to electronic process controls. All three programs also earn college credits that can be applied to an associate's degree.

RACC's AMIST program offers two instructional delivery models to choose from:

  • All training, both theory and hands-on, conducted on-site at the Schmidt Training and Technology Center (STTC). Training available whenever lab is open.
  • Instructional media accessed over the Internet with instructor support; hands-on skills taught and assessed at the Schmidt Training and Technology Center on current industry equipment. Access to the Internet training site is 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

In both models, instructors with relevant industry experience are available to guide students through the program.
title: Advanced Manufacturing Integrated Systems Technology Program (AMIST)
